final_poem:
# Loss, the Season

The orchard dropped its weight before the fall—
each fruit separating from the tree
the way a word leaves the mouth,
meaning already gone.

I found it on the ground, still partly red,
the bruise already darkening.
Hold something that has fallen fully
and understand: the grip was never strong enough.

There is a kind of absence that makes room
for everything else. The table set but for one chair.
The yard wide open to the evening light.
Loss organizes the ordinary into presence—
the dog's head on the pillow, the cup
left out as if for sharing,
the window you keep moving toward
because the view keeps changing
and you want to see what comes next.

What comes next is not a replacement.
It is the afternoon arriving earlier
at the kitchen window, or the cardinal
that lands on the frozen feeder
as if to say: something else, yes—
but also, this was never yours,
this thinning orchard, these empty rooms,
this body that holds weight
only while standing in it.

You will find your hands still open.
That is what loss does:
it teaches you to hold
whatever arrives without guarantee,
to let the cup be half-full
or empty or the shape
that happens at the last moment
to fit whatever's there.
